column3: the Lewis and Clark Expedition camped in the Pasco area
column4: at a site now commemorated by Sacajawea State Park. The area was frequented by fur trappers and gold traders. In the 1880s
column5: the Northern Pacific Railway was built near the Columbia River
column6: bringing many settlers to the area. Pasco was officially incorporated on September 3
column7: 1891. It was named by Virgil Bogue
column8: a construction engineer for the Northern Pacific Railway after Cerro de Pasco
column9: a city in the Peruvian Andes
column10: where he had helped build a railroad. In its early years Pasco was a small railroad town
column11: but the completion of the Grand Coulee Dam in 1941 brought irrigation and agriculture to the area.

column1: Pasco was not a sundown town in the same way as Richland and Kennewick
column2: however Jim Crow laws restricted African Americans to living only on the east side of the railroad tracks
column3: which was largely underdeveloped without public water or garbage service. In the 1940s
column4: Edward R. Dudley visited as an investigator from the NAACP and observed widespread discrimination from businesses and law enforcement. In a 1947 survey

column6: and racial discrimination as second. White residents listed over-crowded schools as the most significant problem
column7: and the presence of Blacks as second. In 1948
column8: Hazel Scott was refused service at a Pasco restaurant and successfully sued the owners for discrimination
column9: bringing national attention to racial segregation practices in the Tri-Cities.In the late 1990s
column11: several developers purchased large farm circles in Pasco for residential and commercial development.  Since that time
column12: Pasco has undergone a transformation that has not only seen its population overtake the neighboring city of Richland
column13: but also has resulted in growth in the city's retail and tourism industries. Recently incorporated land on the West side of the city has exploded into new housing tracts
column15: and shopping centers. This area of the city has become referred to locally as "West Pasco"
column16: distinguishing it from the older area of town to the East.  In addition to an influx of new residents to the region

column1: Pasco has the Council-Manager form of government with an elected body of 7 council members
column2: 6 of whom are from specific districts within the city
column3: and 1 elected at-large.  The council biennially elects from its own members a mayor that runs meetings
column4: signs certain documents
column5: and acts in ceremonial capacity; and a mayor pro-tem that acts in the mayor's absence.  The city manager is chosen by the council as a professional administrator and runs day-to-day operations of the city including management of staff. Council members are part-time legislators.  Those elected 2017 and after receive $1
column6: 115 per month and the mayor receives $1
column7: 450 a month.The city also has a number of advisory boards appointed by the council and includes citizen volunteers that give their time and expertise in dealing with issues including parks

column1: Pasco High School is the older of the city's two public high schools
column2: and was the largest in the state before Chiawana was built. The city's second high school—Chiawana High School—opened in August 2009. Chiawana is currently the largest high school in this area of the state. The Pasco Bulldog school colors are purple and white; the Chiawana Riverhawk school colors are navy blue and silver.  In spring 2015
column3: Delta High School (or DHS) opened in Pasco. It provides a STEM-based curriculum for students in grades 9–12 from three school districts in the Tri-Cities area. The school is operated as a collaborative effort by the Kennewick School District
column4: Pasco School District
column6: and in partnerships with a local skill center
column8: and businesses. The school has been designated by the state as an Existing Innovative School.

column2: Columbia Basin College is the largest public two-year community college in Southeastern Washington with a student body of nearly 7
column3: 000 students.  The college was founded in 1955 and serves students from the entire Tri-Cities region.

Among all of Pasco's annual activities and events
column2: the most popular is the Pasco Farmers Market
column3: located in downtown Pasco. The market is open from May through October each year
column4: drawing a large regional crowd and providing an outlet for farmers selling fresh produce.

column1: The Fiery Foods Festival is another popular event held each September.  This one-day event celebrates spicy foods of all varieties
column2: and highlights the thriving Hispanic culture in the city.

column1: Pasco's Gesa Stadium hosts the Tri-City Dust Devils baseball club of the Northwest League.  The Dust Devils are a Class A team of the San Diego Padres.  The team plays during summer months during its short season.
The Pasco School District's renovated Edgar Brown Memorial Stadium
column2: constructed in a former gravel pit used in the construction of the Blue Bridge (Pioneer Memorial Bridge)
